headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Deshonda [ph] and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Iron Mountain First Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the conferen
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Deshonda [ph] and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Iron Mountain First Quarter Results Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Melissa Marsden, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Please, go ahead.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Deshonda, and welcome everyone to our First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we'll hear from Bill Meaney, our President and CEO, who will discuss highlights of the quarter and progress toward our strategic initiative; follow
componenttext:
Thank you, Deshonda, and welcome everyone to our First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. This morning, we'll hear from Bill Meaney, our President and CEO, who will discuss highlights of the quarter and progress toward our strategic initiative; followed by Rod Day, our CFO, who will cover financial results. 
After our prepared remarks, we'll open up the phones for Q&A. And as we have done in the past, we have posted our earnings commentary and supplemental disclosure package on the Investor Relations page of our website at www.ironmountain.com under Investor Relations/Financial Information. 
Referring now to Page 2 of the supplemental, today's earnings call and slide presentation will contain a number of forward-looking statements, most notably our outlook for 2016 financial and operating performance. All forward-looking statements are subject to risks and uncertainties. Please refer to today's supplemental, our earnings commentary, the Safe Harbor language on this slide and our most recently filed annual report on Form 10-K for a discussion of the major risk factors that could cause our actual results to differ from those in our forward-looking statements. 
In addition, we use several non-GAAP measures when presenting our financial results, and the reconciliations to these measures, as required by Reg G, are included in our supplemental reporting  package. 
With that, Bill, would you please begin?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Melissa, and good morning, everyone. And thanks to all the investors and analysts on today's calls for your continued support during the process of finalizing our acquisition of Recall. In fact, it was 1 year ago today that we announced the agr
componenttext:
Thank you, Melissa, and good morning, everyone. And thanks to all the investors and analysts on today's calls for your continued support during the process of finalizing our acquisition of Recall. In fact, it was 1 year ago today that we announced the agreement in principle between our 2 firms. 
As you saw last week, we have now satisfied all conditions for closing and we'll do so next Monday, Australian time. I cannot say enough good things about the dedication and focus required by -- required and demonstrated by our teams on both sides to get this transaction over the goal line. And I should add, it is this dedication of our teams that has set us up to hit the ground running with integration. I wish to thank my fellow team members for continued focus on the core business by delivering another strong quarter across all metrics but most importantly, our earnings and cash flow results. 
What does this acquisition means for Iron Mountain? From a commercial perspective, it enhances our global footprint, both strengthening our existing country presence as well as expanding our reach from 41 countries to 45 countries and strengthens our ability to reach both global organizations in mid-market businesses looking to benefit from our industry-leading expertise and solutions appropriate for their scale. 
The combined strength of our companies expands our ability to meet customer's information management and storage needs as they face increasing regulation, ongoing security threats and seek to turn information into business value. 
You may remember a video we featured in our Investor Day last fall, with customer stories about the trust they place in us. Today, the stakes have never been higher for organizations of all sizes to ensure their most critical assets are protected and accessible. The see us as their partner protecting what matters, while also providing expertise, products and services designed to get the most out of those assets. That trust is a cornerstone of our business. 
A big part of this trust is based not only on our dedication to high quality service, but it is also derived from confidence our customers have in us to leverage our scale for the kind of innovation that allows us to serve them long into the future. The industrial logic of this deal is undisputable. And from a financial perspective, it enhances our 2020 strategic plan, delivering cash benefits that drive accretion, both on an FFO and an AFFO basis. This in turn supports attractive long-term durable dividend growth, averaging 10% per year through 2018 as the synergies and benefits from transformation begin to flow through and approximately 4% growth per year annually thereafter through 2020. 
I won't go into the detail of synergies and accretion here, as I believe we covered that thoroughly in the call we hosted on April 1  to announce the conclusion of regulatory reviews in the U.S, Canada and Australia. But I do wish to reiterate that the benefits of the transaction are compelling, consistent with our strategy and importantly, consistent with our expectations in terms of the financial contribution. 
Now that closing is imminent, the challenging work of integration can begin. We have been refining and advancing integration plans across all functional areas of the combined companies and it is encouraging to see how well the teams have come together to support the closing and prepare for a smooth combination. We look forward to welcoming Recall customers, and shareholders. 
Starting in Iron Mountain standalone results, first quarter financial and operating results were strong. Our financial results continued to demonstrated the durability of our core storage rental business. Total revenue growth in constant dollars of roughly 4% was in line with our longer-term expectations, driven by constant dollar growth of 4% in both storage and service. 
Adjusted OIBDA constant dollar growth was about 7%, excluding charges associated with our Transformation Program and service initiative. We see consistent trends in constant dollar storage revenue growth for the remainder of the year, while constant dollar service revenue growth will continue to be a bit lumpy. Even with this lumpiness, we continue to expect positive internal service revenue as well as service gross profit growth for the full year. 
Our results from the first quarter reflect the service revenue mix shift we've discussed in recent calls with declines in transportation and handling-related services, largely offset by growth in trading, project revenue and DMS, which for Iron Mountain refers to our imaging or scanning businesses. 
We are also beginning to gain some traction with new data management service offerings, such as our Secure IT asset destruction offering and our data domain venture with EMC. You may have also seen that yesterday, we announced a new Iron Mountain cloud archive offering, a cost-effective, near infinitely-scalable repository for organizations needing to protect and preserve data for compliance, legal or value creation purposes. We'll be debuting this new solution at EMC World Conference next week. 
As our mix shift continues, we will focus more on enhancing gross profit rather than gross margins as these new service offerings are often lower-margin but still generate attractive returns due to the minimal capital investment required. 
Turning to internal storage revenue, growth of 2.2% for the quarter was in line with the fourth quarter of last year and is compared with a particularly strong quarter in 2015. We continue to expect average storage rental internal growth to be north of 2.5% for the full year. Internal volume growth or net of acquisitions was positive in all segments and consistent with recent quarters' performance at 1 2 -- 1.6% worldwide growth. Total gross volume or records from new and existing customers was roughly 30.5 million cubic feet over the trailing 12 months, also very consistent with what we've seen over the past few years. 
Turning to progress on our strategic plan, during the quarter, we continue to advance each of the 3 pillars of the plan as well as in the foundational elements that support it. Let me briefly highlight progress in each of the 3 pillars, namely getting the most out of our developed markets; expanding our presence in the fast-growing emerging markets; and expansion in faster growing adjacent businesses. 
In developed markets, we achieved consistent performance from North America RIM with positive internal storage and volume growth, while North American data management and our Western Europe segment both generated internal volume growth of roughly 3% and total internal revenue growth of about 2%. 
In emerging markets, our goal is to expand our presence and leverage our scale, driving these markets to 20% of our total revenue by 2020. Recall footprint in Southeast Asia will support that objective but prior to the combination, we already have driven our emerging market business to 15% of total revenue on a constant dollar basis as of the end of Q1. 
During the quarter, we continue to achieve total internal revenue growth in these markets of 10%, with internal volume growth of 7%. Additionally, as our visibility on closing of the Recall transaction became clear, we resumed acquisition activity, moving into 2 new emerging markets during the quarter. We acquired a 75% interest in the largest privately-owned and the #2 overall records management company in South Africa, a company with more than 2 million cubic feet of storage and a range of offering similar to ours. 
We also acquired a Lithuanian-based document storage and archiving firm during the quarter, expanding our presence into 3 new countries in the Baltics, with the acquisition of this market leader. 
With these acquisitions, we expand our global reach and now operate in 41 countries on 6 continents. But it's not about putting pins in the map. It's about leveraging our global footprint, and capturing the first wave of records management outsourcing occurring in these faster growing markets. 
As we noted last quarter, we did see the carryover of the large single customer destruction in our Other International segment, which drove destructions up to 4.2% in this segment, in line with what we saw last quarter. Again, we do not see any other such unusual destructions on the horizon and expect that the remainder of the year, we'll return to more typical levels of less than 4%. We do report volume change on a trailing 12 month basis and if this level will remain slightly elevated over the next few quarters. 
As for adjacent businesses, we are on track to achieve our stated goal to generate 5% of our total worldwide revenue from adjacent businesses by the end of 2020, up from just 2% at the end of 2015. You can now see a full quarter of contribution from Crozier Fine Arts acquired last December, which is performing in line with our expectations. 
Additionally, you may have noted our plans to expand our data center business into Northern Virginia, North America's largest data center market. Northern Virginia is also home to federal government data centers and large bio data centers owned by the major data center REITs. 
During Q2, we plan to resolve this land to an industrial developer, who will undertake land development and shell construction, whilst we focus on expanding our data center product offering in this highly desirable location. We are early in the planning for this multiyear, multi-phased project. Whilst we are not yet showing specific projections, we wanted to share our plans, provide some insight into one of the ways in which we are able to strategically fund our growth opportunities. 
The result is that whilst we will achieve slightly lower-margins through this approach to funding, the impact on our balance sheet has improved and our stabilized ROIC is similar to that of data centers we own outright. 
To sum up, we are well on track to achieve our combined goal of having the expansion of our emerging market presence and adjacent businesses yield 25% of our total revenue mix by 2020, with the internal growth rates in the 10% plus range, which is up from a little over 17% of our business mix today. 
I should also add, we continue to make progress in our transformation initiatives. Actions in 2015 resulted in run rate savings of $50 million, which is visible in a 120-basis point improvement in year-over-year OIBDA margins this quarter, after adjusting for transformation. 
We have undertaken additional action in the first quarter that support the additional $50 million of savings we expect to achieve by year end 2016. 
We incurred total charges of $5.7 million in the quarter related to these actions and we're able to pull forward a bit of the run rate savings that contributed to our strong performance this quarter. 
Also, as previously disclosed, the remainder of the total $125 million of overhead savings will be actioned [ph] in 2017 and the full amount for the transformation program will be reflected in our 2018 adjusted OIBDA. 
The all-important cash flow result for both today and growth into the future is in line with the growth expectations we highlighted during Investor Day, and again, on our April 1 call, and continues to provide the foundation for our expected dividend growth. We also updated the high-level goals associated with our 2020 plan. What we've communicated is that we continue to expect to achieve similar top line and adjusted OIBDA compound annual growth. We also expect to generate similar levels of cash available to grow the dividend by an average of about 10% per year through 2018 and 4% annual growth thereafter, fund organic growth racking investment and increase the amount of remaining cash available to support discretionary investment. And we will do so whilst both reducing our payout ratio as a percentage of AFFO and deleveraging. 
We expect to fund additional growth through debt financing in amounts that allows us to continue to delever the business on a debt-to-EBITDA basis. 
Our expectations are underpinned by the continued demonstration of a very durable growing business that performs consistently throughout business cycles. 
In addition, we are extending that durability through solid execution of our plan in developed market, identifying and capturing opportunities in both emerging markets and adjacent businesses and continuing to enhance our cost structure in both service and overhead. Our durable storage business generates more than $1.5 billion of annual storage net operating income, which is comparable to that generated by leaders in both the industrial and self-storage sectors. 
What distinguishes our business is its inherent durability and this durability that delivers consistent levels of operating performance in good and bad times. 
With that, I'd like to turn the call over to Rod.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. I'll begin today with an overview of our first quarter performance, including an update on our transformation initiative and the review of results by segments. Then I will provide color on the Recall transaction and progress we've made so fa
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. I'll begin today with an overview of our first quarter performance, including an update on our transformation initiative and the review of results by segments. Then I will provide color on the Recall transaction and progress we've made so far in preparing for integration as well as discuss our plans for funding the transaction. 
Let's turn to our worldwide financial results. For the first quarter, reported revenues were $751 million compared with $749 million in 2015. Excluding the year-over-year FX impact of approximately 3.6% or $26 million on a constant dollar basis, revenues grew by 3.8%. 
Total revenues were driven by a strong constant dollar storage rental revenue growth of approximately 3.9%. 
Service revenues also performed well in the quarter, up by 3.7%. This was primarily the result of project revenue in North American Records and Information Management and growth in shred revenues, driven by new customer wins. This service revenue growth reflects the mix shift in our business, with service revenues are more heavily weighted towards projects, which can result in more volatility in year-over-year growth rates. 
During the quarter, we saw a reduction in service gross profits and service gross margin. This decline was driven by an increase in medical expenses and severance costs related to our service gross margin initiative. Excluding these costs, service gross margins would've been flat on a year-over-year basis. 
Consistent with prior quarters, we have provided Britain schedules for total revenue, adjusted OIBDA and adjusted earnings per share, which explain key variances in year-on-year performance for the quarter. 
This quarter, we've also added a similar bridge for Echo focus [ph] share. These schedules on Page 20 through 23 of the supplemental. 
Total adjusted OIBDA for the quarter was $235 million compared to $231 million in 2015. Despite FX headwinds earlier in the year, we grew adjusted OIBDA by 1.7% and by 4.5% on a constant dollar basis, and growth was 7%, if we exclude the $5.7 million of transformation initiative charges we took in the quarter. 
As evidenced by improvements at the whole adjusted OIBDA margins, we continue to execute on our transformation initiative. As just stated, during this quarter, we incurred roughly $6 million of net charges related to this initiative. 
During Q2 and Q3, prior to any adjustments from Recall, we continue to expect the transformation initiative to be $1 million to $2 million net negative to adjusted OIBDA, with in-quarter costs slightly offsetting benefits. 
In Q4, we expect a net upside of roughly $7 million, providing a strong run rate platform for year-on-year benefits, 2017. 
We continue to expect exit rate savings from actions taken in 2016 of $50 million to flow through to 2017. Our overall savings outlook for transformation remains consistent with what we laid out on our Investor Day in October, with $125 million of cumulative savings by 2018. 
Adjusted EPS for the quarter was $0.33 compared to $0.32 in 2010. Excluding the cost for the transformation and after normalizing for the tax rate benefit, adjusted EPS would've grown by roughly 9%. 
Our adjusted OIBDA on an adjusted EPS results for the quarter came in ahead of the phasing expectations we laid out on the February conference call. This OIBDA performance in the first quarter was driven by pulling forward a portion of transformation benefits as well as lower overall G&A expenses as we delayed certain costs and hires in anticipation of the Recall transaction.  In addition, adjusted EPS benefited from a lower tax rate. 
Our structural tax rate for this quarter came out at 14.0% compared to 16.2% in the prior year. The year-over-year decrease in our structural tax rate was primarily driven by earnings mix skewed more towards our qualified nontaxable entities. 
We continue to believe that our tax rate will be roughly 20% once Recall closes due to their exposure in International markets. 
Normalized funds from operations or FFO per share was $0.51 for the quarter compared to $0.50 in the year-ago period. As noted in the cost associated with the transformation, FFO per share would have grown by roughly 8%. 
Adjusted funds from operations or AFFO was $142 million compared with $128 million in the year-ago period. AFFO is at the high-end of expectations due to the timing of maintenance capital expenses and nonreal estate investments which are typically incurred towards the second half of the year. 
Similar to the prior quarter, on Page 19 of the supplemental, we're providing a reconciliation between AFFO and cash flow from operations as presented in our GAAP cash flow statement, so you can more readily see the cash items that are not of the typical recurring nature. 
Let's turn to our financial performance by segment. In North American Records and Information Management or RIM, internal storage rental revenue increased by 0.2% for the first quarter. North American RIM internal service revenue increased by 3.8% due to an increase in project rate revenue and new customer wins from the shred business, as noted earlier. 
North American RIM adjusted OIBDA margins declined year-over-year, primarily due to increased medical costs and severance charges related to our service margin initiative. 
North American Data Management or DM delivered storage rental internal growth of 1.8% for the first quarter. Internal service revenue in DM declined by 6.9%, as we continue to see reductions in the frequency of tape rotation on related transportation activity in the business. 
The high single-digit decline in transportation and handling services was partially offset by mid-single digit growth in the new data management service offerings and other DM project-related revenue. 
DM adjusted OIBDA margins improved year-over-year due to an increase -- due to decrease in overhead costs, primarily associated with lower G&A expense. 
The Western European segment generated solid results, with 2.1% internal storage rental growth. Internal service revenue growth decline in this segment, primarily as a result of activity declines in retrieved refund in transportation and a relatively weak quarter for projects. 
Adjusted OIBDA margins improved in Western Europe as a result of a decrease in overhead expense, specifically compensation expense. In addition, Western Europe benefited from a one-off real estate tax benefit of roughly $3 million. 
The other International segments, which is made up primarily of emerging markets in Australia, showed strong growth in both storage and service revenues. Storage rental internal growth was 9.6% and service internal growth, 11.3% for the quarter. Other International adjusted OIBDA margins were 21% for the quarter, in line with expectations. 
We continue to expect adjusted OIBDA in this segment to deliver profitability on a portfolio basis in the low 20s range in the short-term as we expand our exposure in these fast-growing markets. 
Let me talk about the Recall acquisition to provide details on the cost we have incurred so far in 2016. We're working diligently on integration planning as well as preparing to convert portions of Recall's business to our infrastructure. 
As a result of all this hard work, we are well-positioned to achieve our synergies quicker in 2016 than we have originally anticipated when we announced the deal back in June 2015. Our expectations of cost to achieve the deal still consistent with prior projections. 
In the first quarter, we incurred $7 million of deal closed cost and $11 million of integration related cost, bringing the total of Recall costs in Q1 to roughly $18 million in operating expenses. Please note these expenses are excluded from our adjusted OIBDA calculations that are onetime in nature. 
Let's turn to our outlook for 2016 on Page 12 of the supplemental. Business trends and fundamentals remain consistent. We remain on track to achieve our long-term financial objectives, given the durability and strong fundamentals of our business. As we noted, our 2016 guidance reflects a partial year benefit from Recall as well as the net synergies we are expecting in 2016. Please note, this is a preliminary view of the combined group and assumes that all divestitures are effective on May 1. We'll continue to refine our estimates and provide updates as necessary once the transaction is closed. 
Another point about the guidance, as you might expect, even though we're combining our higher-margin business with Recall's slightly lower-margin business, in the near term, adjusted OIBDA margins will be slightly lower and our standalone margins until we realize synergies. 
Lastly, I'd like to note that we are starting to see improvement in foreign currencies against the U.S. dollar, which may potentially add some favorability to our 2016 guidance. The top currencies that have improved since the beginning of the year are the Canadian dollar, euro, Brazilian rail [ph] and Australian dollar, partially offset by the declines in the British pound. We're continuing to watch these trends closely and we'll update our guidance once warranted. 
Moving to our expected cash available for distribution investment for 2016, we continue to estimate that it will be roughly $600 million for 2016. This continues to provide ample dividend coverage and funds our core growth racking investments. Our capital deployment plans remain unchanged. We continue to expect capital expenditures, which include real estate and nonreal estate maintenance and nonreal estate investment to be in line with the figures we provided on April 1. We expect to send -- spend $70 million in core growth racking and approximately $35 million in the data center business. 
For M&A, our plan continues to be roughly $100 million spend in emerging markets and $50 million in developed markets. We also plan on investing where value creation is compelling in real estate development consolidation and lease conversions. 
Dividend expectations remain consistent with the guidance we laid out on our Investor Day. Dividend per share is expected to grow in the double digits on average in 2017 and 2018 as we realize the benefits of transformation savings and Recall synergies. Beyond 2018, we expect to grow dividend per share of roughly 4% per year. Importantly, the dividend payout ratio as a percentage of AFFO, is expected to be approximately 78% in 2016 and 70% by 2020, which underscores the strength of our dividend coverage. 
Shifting briefly to the balance sheet, at the year end, we had liquidity of approximately $650 million and our lease adjusted debt ratio was 5.7x as expected. 
We announced last week that we entered into a commitment letter with lenders to provide an unsecured bridge facility of up to $850 million to provide a portion of the financing for the Recall transaction. We expect to enter into definitive loan documentation for the bridge and borrow the full amount on April 29. 
As previously said, we anticipate refinancing the bridge and replenishing capacity on the revolver with long-term debt as soon as practical. 
Overall, we are pleased with the strong performance we saw in the first quarter. Our results are driven by the durability of our business and execution of our 2020 Vision. We are excited to begin the integration of Recall in the second quarter and begin to realize meaningful synergies associated with the deal. 
Looking ahead, we believe we are well-positioned to deliver on our short-term and long term goals. We remain focused on extending the durability of our storage rental business, which drives growth and our cash available to fund dividends in the core growth investments. 
And with that, I'll hand the call back to Bill.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Rod. And before I turn the call back over to the operator for questions, let me quickly sum up what you've heard today so far. First, this was a very good quarter and we are headed into the Recall integration from a strong position. Our core
componenttext:
Thank you, Rod. And before I turn the call back over to the operator for questions, let me quickly sum up what you've heard today so far. 
First, this was a very good quarter and we are headed into the Recall integration from a strong position. Our core storage business performed well and remains extremely durable, a characteristic that has been demonstrated both in good economic conditions as well as through downturns. And if you Recall, last year, we finished the year with a 1.5% internal revenue growth rate, before acquisitions and now Q1 results showed a 2% internal revenue growth rate, which also compares favorably to the Q1 of last year at 1.4%.  So it was a good quarter also in terms of revenue growth. 
Second, we're feeling good about the Recall transaction. Our progress in integration and the ability to derive benefits from scale, which supports additional growth in cash flow. 
And finally, our high-margin business coupled with our focus and continuous cost control continues to give us high confidence in our ability to deploy that incremental cash flow into growth investment, deleveraging and near-term double-digit growth in our dividend per share. 
With that, operator, we're now ready for questions.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the North American tape business, services internal revenue decline remained elevated, which suggest that we're still early in the cycle in terms of rotation of revenue decline process. When do you expect the decline in services there to normalize? Can
componenttext: In the North American tape business, services internal revenue decline remained elevated, which suggest that we're still early in the cycle in terms of rotation of revenue decline process. When do you expect the decline in services there to normalize? Can you provide a status report on some of the newer services initiative you have that can help offset the headwinds?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we still don't see much of it in abating of that trend. So we're not predicting the bottom. I mean, I think I've said a few times, it's -- on the records management side, we have seen a flattening out but on the tape, it's a little bit behind the curve
componenttext: So we still don't see much of it in abating of that trend. So we're not predicting the bottom. I mean, I think I've said a few times, it's -- on the records management side, we have seen a flattening out but on the tape, it's a little bit behind the curve, What's encouraging is we see high single-digit, low double-digit quarter declines in the -- what I would call the transportation or rotating the tapes, as you say, part of the service business. But we see mid-single-digit growth in those new services, which is what allows us to offset the rate of decline. So we do see -- albeit off a small base but we do see significant impact in terms of growth at some of these new service offerings like the service offering I highlighted on the call with EMC.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, looking ahead to the company, pro forma for Recall, can you discuss what your expectations are for Recall's fundamental performance? What assumptions are embedded in your guidance with Recall? And if your due diligence findings confirm R
componenttext: Got it. And then, looking ahead to the company, pro forma for Recall, can you discuss what your expectations are for Recall's fundamental performance? What assumptions are embedded in your guidance with Recall? And if your due diligence findings confirm Recall's existing guidance?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll let Ron answer that in more detail aspect of the questions. But I think -- I'll just touch a bit upon your last part of your question in terms of what we found with integration planning with Recall. And I think what we've -- the main difference that
componenttext: I'll let Ron answer that in more detail aspect of the questions. But I think -- I'll just touch a bit upon your last part of your question in terms of what we found with integration planning with Recall. And I think what we've -- the main difference that we've talked about on the April 1 call, is we found -- what I would call more capital efficiencies. So 2 [ph] various specifically is what we found in terms of maintenance CapEx, we feel very comfortable that Recall's maintenance CapEx will be in line with what we spend on our [indiscernible] facilities, i.e. around 2.6% of revenue, whereas before we though we were going to have to spend more because they have done a number of acquisitions. So we feel very comfortable based on the integration planning that it's kind of like-for-like integration in terms of level of maintenance Capex. The other area in which we feel very comfortable now, which was an unknown for us, is we had a significant uptick or regional budgeting for IT systems because again we didn't know if our platforms would be big enough to scale efficiently to absorb all of the Recall operations. And again, we feel very confident to see that we still have significant investment to absorb the Recall operations onto our IT platforms. But much more in line that we're taking on a company that's 1/4 of our size, rather than one that we would have to rebuild or relaunch major IT systems. So those are the 2 areas that I would say a positive surprises that we had on the integration side. But Rod, you may want to comment a little bit more in terms of the guidance.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, in terms of the assumptions we've made for the Recall performance for the remainder of this year, is essentially is consistent with the performance that we've seen over recent periods. So we just trended that forward. So it's a modest underlying grow
componenttext: Yes, in terms of the assumptions we've made for the Recall performance for the remainder of this year, is essentially is consistent with the performance that we've seen over recent periods. So we just trended that forward. So it's a modest underlying growth within the business of around 2% in this acquisition benefit, on top of that. And margins being very broadly consistent. So we've not assumed any inflection points up or down in terms of performances to continuation of the trend.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Steinerman with JPMorgan.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'd like to spend more time on the service and total growth of 3.8%. I did cash, but you said it is more project-oriented. But this is kind of a massive standout, if you kind of look over the last 4 quarters versus 3.8% growth, can you just give us a sens
componenttext: I'd like to spend more time on the service and total growth of 3.8%. I did cash, but you said it is more project-oriented. But this is kind of a massive standout, if you kind of look over the last 4 quarters versus 3.8% growth, can you just give us a sense of do you feel like there was anything that was particularly one time? Or are these projects -- that should come up regularly? And do you think that service revenues will grow for the year with the amount in written?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it's a good question, Andrew. So first of all, I would say that they are specific projects but not necessarily onetime in nature. In other words, we're not saying is we expect to continue to have these kinds of projects that we fell as we go through. B
componenttext: So it's a good question, Andrew. So first of all, I would say that they are specific projects but not necessarily onetime in nature. In other words, we're not saying is we expect to continue to have these kinds of projects that we fell as we go through. But they're not -- these are -- it could be a project for company X today and companywide tomorrow. So these are discrete projects but not ones that we don't expect to have a recurring pattern. That being said, which I said both in my remarks and I think Rod also mentioned in his remarks as they tend to be more lumpy. So I wouldn't change our guidance in terms of overall growth, in terms of revenue. Because you will see some up-and-downs on that. So I would keep the guidance the same. That's our expectation. But it is an area, you're right to call it out. It is an area that we're putting more and more discrete focus on as a safe initiative because we're hearing from our customers, they are looking for more and more kinds of what I would call project-related services as we kind of take the full management of their document from creation to storage approach. So just by the very nature, it's more project-related. We are focused more of our attention on providing those kinds of services for our customers so you can expect continued growth in that area. But it will be lumpy.

componenttextpreview: But do you think it will be positive for the year?
componenttext: But do you think it will be positive for the year?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me do that. So if we look at the same periods last year, our service gross margin was 26.1% and this quarter, we came in at 24.3%. There's really 2 key factors that's driving the difference. One is we had an increase in medical costs year-over-year, t
componenttext: Let me do that. So if we look at the same periods last year, our service gross margin was 26.1% and this quarter, we came in at 24.3%. There's really 2 key factors that's driving the difference. One is we had an increase in medical costs year-over-year, that accounts for 1.0% of that differential. And the second is we took some severance cost in a number of our services businesses as part of sort of an ongoing program to drive longer-term improvements in margin. And that has an impact of 0.6%. There's a small other component, which has to do with some vacation accruals, if you were to factor those in, we'd actually would've had a service gross margin of 26.2%. So that would compare to 26.1% from last year. So that's the driver of the difference.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then one thing I would add, so if you would expect our margins to be kind of similar year-on-year because the mix haven't shifted that much. But what we said I think in the last couple of calls, what you see over time is not that we're not focused on
componenttext: And then one thing I would add, so if you would expect our margins to be kind of similar year-on-year because the mix haven't shifted that much. But what we said I think in the last couple of calls, what you see over time is not that we're not focused on margins but we're less focused on specific margin number because we're looking at return on invested capital as the mix of services change. Because as Rod said, answering the question earlier, about what's happening with transportation for instance or our data management or tape business, the tape -- the transportation typically is very high-margin business. So as we plant some of that revenue loss with new service initiatives, many of those have a lower-margin but they also have lower capital associated with similar returns. But I think the bridge year-on-year, you're not going to see a massive change in mix over time. So I think the bridge is important when on a short period of time, assuming that's been happening.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

componenttext: And then the decline in maintenance CapEx, do the timing of Recall acquisition? Or some other item?

componenttext: Yes, again as I referred to that in the prepared remarks, it is a timing issue. We typically see spend more for maintenance Capex in the back half of the year than in the first half. And so it's a similar trend that we're seeing this year. Well obviously, to your point, who will effectively we will evaluating as well sort of post close the result of the moment of guidance on that for the full-year still stands.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was just hoping that you can talk a little bit about the pricing characteristics by the major markets that you break out, Bill? If you're seeing any change in the marketplace? That will be helpful.
componenttext: I was just hoping that you can talk a little bit about the pricing characteristics by the major markets that you break out, Bill? If you're seeing any change in the marketplace? That will be helpful.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. I think I understand the question beyond the question because in some of the markets we highlighted, there are some of the segments we highlighted the volume is growing faster than the revenue, if I understand where your question i
componenttext: That's a good question. I think I understand the question beyond the question because in some of the markets we highlighted, there are some of the segments we highlighted the volume is growing faster than the revenue, if I understand where your question is coming from. I think the -- I wouldn't read too much into that. I think generally, our guidance is the same, that we're achieving inflation or a little bit more than inflation in terms of pricing in each of our markets. So it does look a little bit odd in this quarter that you see in a couple of segments where we actually achieved higher volume growth and total revenue growth on a storage basis. I think that's more driven by a couple of things. One is that in one of our business lines, we had a major REIT, a very large customer, major renewal. And I think as we talked about before, when we have large customer renewals is you get these sawtooth where at the renewal point is you take a discount and then it climbs up through that period. So it was a little bit of that going on. And then, specifically in Europe, we have a market where we successfully took on a very large public sector customer, which has actually similar pricing as a lot of our other developed markets, but because of the historical volume of some customers just reaching their natural light for some of the box is as natural customers reaching their natural life going out at the same time. You have a -- what actually, looks like a dilution effect. But overall, our pricing still continues to track. If we look at it over a 12 or kind of a trailing basis, we expect it to continue to track to be slightly ahead of inflation. So you'll kind of see that kind of go back into the normal zone.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then, just another question to ask is maybe year ago, but I thought maybe, I'd ask it again now, which is your view on Iron Mountain's need and desire to be in shredding as the company gets bigger, as still another year into the REIT, I want t
componenttext: Got it. And then, just another question to ask is maybe year ago, but I thought maybe, I'd ask it again now, which is your view on Iron Mountain's need and desire to be in shredding as the company gets bigger, as still another year into the REIT, I want to understand your thoughts on that business.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as I probably said a year ago, we like all our businesses, we never fall in love with any of our businesses. So I would say the same thing about shred or any of our portfolio businesses. I think, look, we're getting some good growth out of the bus
componenttext: I think as I probably said a year ago, we like all our businesses, we never fall in love with any of our businesses. So I would say the same thing about shred or any of our portfolio businesses. I think, look, we're getting some good growth out of the business. When we sold off the Australian and the U.K. business, I guess, a little over a year ago, that was because we didn't think those markets we had the skill to actually do it. I think we're getting a nice turn around or improvement in our business in North America. That being said, we look at all of our businesses but not just shred. We look in geographies, some businesses and geographies. We look at it on a portfolio basis. And if at some point we feel that there is a better owner for either business line or even a geography of a -- what you might think even a core business line, we would consider that. So there are no plans, but we're pretty disciplined on our capital allocation approach across our portfolio management.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I have one thing to have on credits. It's not a short-term performance problem for us. During the last few quarters, we've seen some good traction in terms of new customer wins, which has helped this revenue and there's been some good work done as
componenttext: I think I have one thing to have on credits. It's not a short-term performance problem for us. During the last few quarters, we've seen some good traction in terms of new customer wins, which has helped this revenue and there's been some good work done as that's been driving the underlying efficiencies within the business. We also saw the paper price for shred -- recycled paper started to stabilize.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That was actually, my follow-up. You guys mentioned that shredding is up. Is that paper price driven or new customer driven? Or you could you parse that out for us?
componenttext: That was actually, my follow-up. You guys mentioned that shredding is up. Is that paper price driven or new customer driven? Or you could you parse that out for us?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's primarily driven by new customers. So we have a couple of good wins.
componenttext: It's primarily driven by new customers. So we have a couple of good wins.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think we highlighted before. We put a new leader in charge of that business and really kind of put a separate -- almost managing as a separate business unit about a year ago. And he's really doing a standup job on it. He's taking a different approa
componenttext: Yes, I think we highlighted before. We put a new leader in charge of that business and really kind of put a separate -- almost managing as a separate business unit about a year ago. And he's really doing a standup job on it. He's taking a different approach to driving that business. I think too much before we were focused on chasing customers rather than managing windshield time, and that is a business that lends itself to route density. So different approach, very strong leader and as a result we're getting good results from that business.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there -- are you seeing a competitive [indiscernible] with the  ownership change in your competitor there in North America? Or is that a source of the new customers?
componenttext: Is there -- are you seeing a competitive [indiscernible] with the  ownership change in your competitor there in North America? Or is that a source of the new customers?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I wouldn't say that, I mean, I guess you're talking about recycle taking over shredded. I think, look, it's -- our senses was run into separate business units when it was PE back and it was run as a separate business unit back when it had the same lea
componenttext: No, I wouldn't say that, I mean, I guess you're talking about recycle taking over shredded. I think, look, it's -- our senses was run into separate business units when it was PE back and it was run as a separate business unit back when it had the same leader, that business now as it did before when it was owned by the PE firm. So I think it's pretty much the same competitive dynamic that we have before but I think we're just doing a better job quite frankly than we were before. I don't think we're doing a bad job before, but we just have a much more [indiscernible] focus on day-to-day management.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Karin Ford with MUFJ.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Karin Ford with MUFJ.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask about storage rental revenue internal growth. 2.2% in 1Q, I think you said in your remarks that you're still expecting it to be up by roughly 2.5% for the year. What do you think is going to drive the acceleration later on in the year ther
componenttext: I wanted to ask about storage rental revenue internal growth. 2.2% in 1Q, I think you said in your remarks that you're still expecting it to be up by roughly 2.5% for the year. What do you think is going to drive the acceleration later on in the year there? And what are you seeing in terms? Which segments are -- how are they trending?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think a couple of things. One is if you look at the 2.2% this quarter, it's in line with what Q4 was. And as much of anything driven by it, we have a 3% increase in Q1 last year. So it's a quarter-on-quarter, in other words, it's a highly comparable
componenttext: So I think a couple of things. One is if you look at the 2.2% this quarter, it's in line with what Q4 was. And as much of anything driven by it, we have a 3% increase in Q1 last year. So it's a quarter-on-quarter, in other words, it's a highly comparable versus last year's, is the main thing that's driving the -- or one of the main drivers of driving it. The other thing which we said is that we expect a ramp through the year. And we feel like we are well on track. So that's why we said we expect still at the end of the year to end up north of 2.5% in terms of internal storage revenue growth. The other thing you should go back, is important to look at, if we look at year-on-year comparison, if we look at just total internal revenue growth, total internal revenue growth for the company quarter 1 2015 was 1.4% and we have delivered 2% this quarter. And overall last year, we had 1.5% and we delivered 2% this quarter. So we feel comfortable with the rep, even at a total revenue basis that we are achieving. And specifically, if we look at the storage rental revenues, as they say, you need to look at it quarter-on-quarter as we're looking at a very strong quarter in '15 and then we have a natural ramp during the year.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, so easy comps plus around, later on in the year. Got it.
componenttext: Okay, so easy comps plus around, later on in the year. Got it.

componenttextpreview: I would say more normal comps.
componenttext: I would say more normal comps.

componenttextpreview: Normal comps. Okay, got it. A second question, a follow-up on a previous one. The internal service revenue growth performance as you go on 1Q is going to be lumpy for the rest of the year but net positive, are there any quarters that you're expecting from
componenttext: Normal comps. Okay, got it. A second question, a follow-up on a previous one. The internal service revenue growth performance as you go on 1Q is going to be lumpy for the rest of the year but net positive, are there any quarters that you're expecting from here to go negative on that line?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think you can probably appreciate we don't guide by the quarter just by -- we have a lot of confidence that we look out the course of the year because we see the pipeline of projects. But the actual timing of those projects, quite frankly some of those
componenttext: I think you can probably appreciate we don't guide by the quarter just by -- we have a lot of confidence that we look out the course of the year because we see the pipeline of projects. But the actual timing of those projects, quite frankly some of those projects came in earlier in Q1 than we expected. Some of those we thought we're going to come in Q2. So the exact timing of projects are not in our control many times. So we feel comfortable with the pipeline and what we're going to deliver from a year-end result but to give you quarterly guidance, we're not going to do that.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Are you seeing an impact from global economic turmoil on any of your International business today?
componenttext: Okay. Are you seeing an impact from global economic turmoil on any of your International business today?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think [indiscernible] Rod talked about -- we could talk about, we can give you a little bit more flavor about currencies, I mean FX is usually the thing that affects us but it doesn't affect us from liquidity because our cost from revenue are matche
componenttext: No, I think [indiscernible] Rod talked about -- we could talk about, we can give you a little bit more flavor about currencies, I mean FX is usually the thing that affects us but it doesn't affect us from liquidity because our cost from revenue are matched. But generally, that great thing about this business is it's -- maybe I should say battleship, but probably people don't like that analogy, but it just plows through basically any weather. I mean, if you look at the GFC, we had positive rental revenue growth right through the GFC where any of the company or the self storage or industrial storage didn't have that. So first of all, even if we see turmoil, it doesn't really affect our business. And we don't see anything that would affect it  -- even a brick fit, which can probably come up more than I can. So we look at these things all the time. We do -- I do have to say that we're not complacent as a company, as we do look at political risk when we make investments and we think about the political risk both in terms of what could happen in that country in terms of economic turmoil, but also in terms of currency. But Rod, you may want to comment a little bit more on currency?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just 2 things, just in terms of currency as I mentioned in the remarks, we've -- because we've actually seen a slight weakening of the U.S. dollar more recently, and that could be a favorable for us for the full year. So across the basket of currenc
componenttext: Maybe just 2 things, just in terms of currency as I mentioned in the remarks, we've -- because we've actually seen a slight weakening of the U.S. dollar more recently, and that could be a favorable for us for the full year. So across the basket of currency, if things stay as they are, it would be a slight favorable. So that at least, that's negative, if you like for us, just as turnaround I'm sure as with any other global businesses. In terms of economic turmoil in certain markets, it's a good question but it still points out -- we're relatively immune from that, so I could pick examples, such as Russia or Columbia or Brazil, which all in quite difficult straight and more broadly our business actually performing well and to plan in those markets. And it's really to do with the fundamentals of the business, it's a good one to know.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And just last question for you, Rod. Where do you think you could raise long-term debt today? At what cost?
componenttext: Great. And just last question for you, Rod. Where do you think you could raise long-term debt today? At what cost?

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question. We think -- we hope it will be in the sort of 5% to 6% range. But when we go to market, we will see what the conditions are. But we recently raised some U.S. debt a few months ago at 6% when the market conditions actually weren't a
componenttext: That's a good question. We think -- we hope it will be in the sort of 5% to 6% range. But when we go to market, we will see what the conditions are. But we recently raised some U.S. debt a few months ago at 6% when the market conditions actually weren't as favorable as they are now. So hopefully, we can get a bit below that.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: If there's any further questions, operator. So first of all I would like to thank everyone. I know it's a busy time of the year for dialing in and listening in today. And again we're very excited that we think we've had a very good quarter, which is more
componenttext: If there's any further questions, operator. So first of all I would like to thank everyone. I know it's a busy time of the year for dialing in and listening in today. And again we're very excited that we think we've had a very good quarter, which is more importantly is giving us a very strong foundation and entry point into the Recall acquisition, which we're really excited about. And the company hasn't done an acquisition that this transformational probably since the Peers Lady [ph] acquisition, which was done by my predecessor. So we're really looking forward to taking this strong quarter, layering on what Recall can bring, the next stage for growth in the company, both in terms of cash flow and dividend growth. So thank you again and we look forward to speaking to you next quarter.

headline: Iron Mountain Incorporated, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2016
